edu.luc.cs.trull.tl
Class Expr

java.lang.Object
  edu.luc.cs.trull.tl.Expr
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable
Direct Known Subclasses:
AllPast, And, BackTo, Implies, Leaf, Not, Once, Or, Previous, Since
public abstract class Expr
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable

The class Expr is the common abstract superclass for all temporal logic formula classes. TODO THEJUS look at java.util.regex.Pattern.compile and come up with something similar for TL look here for syntax: http://www-step.stanford.edu/tutorial/temporal-logic/temporal-logic.html I propose the following syntax: !, &&, || for the logical operators a=>b implies, a$b since, a#b backto =a sofar (our allpast), +a once, -a previous

Method Summary
(package private)  void accept(Visitor v)
          Traverses the temporal logic formula using a visitor.
 boolean check()
          Returns the value of the formula as it was last eval()uated. subformulas can be ckec()ed.
 java.lang.Object clone()
           
(package private)  boolean ev()
          Evaluates the formula.
 boolean eval()
          Evaluates the formula, by recursively evaluating its subformulas. it is important that only top-level formulas be eval()uated, and only once during each "tick" of the system. each time eval is used on a top-level formula a "tick" takes place. once a formula is evaluated, its value and all its subformulas' value can be obtained through the check() method. in other words, eval modifies the states of the formulas and recurses, check does not.
 boolean eval(java.lang.Object label)
          Evaluates the formula for the given label.

 void reset()
          return time to "zero" by resetting the local state of this formula and all its subformulas. use only on top-level formulas.

          Sets the value of an expression. for obvious reasons, this is only available to base Expr's.

          Advances the clock by one step.

Method Detail

accept

void accept(Visitor v)
Traverses the temporal logic formula using a visitor.

check

public final boolean check()
Returns the value of the formula as it was last eval()uated. subformulas can be ckec()ed.

clone

public java.lang.Object clone()

ev

boolean ev()
Evaluates the formula. It should be overridden by subclasses that represent composite formulas.

eval

public final boolean eval()
Evaluates the formula, by recursively evaluating its subformulas. it is important that only top-level formulas be eval()uated, and only once during each "tick" of the system. each time eval is used on a top-level formula a "tick" takes place. once a formula is evaluated, its value and all its subformulas' value can be obtained through the check() method. in other words, eval modifies the states of the formulas and recurses, check does not.

eval

public final boolean eval(java.lang.Object label)
Evaluates the formula for the given label. Leaves evaluate to true if and only if their label is equal to the given one.

See Also:
Leaf

getFringe

java.util.List getFringe()

getLabels

public java.lang.Object[] getLabels()
Returns the labels that occur in the leaves of this formula.

reset

public void reset()
return time to "zero" by resetting the local state of this formula and all its subformulas. use only on top-level formulas.

set

public final void set(boolean val)
Sets the value of an expression. for obvious reasons, this is only available to base Expr's. NOTE: at each time instant, set must be called with the appropriate value, otherwise, it maintains values across invocations of eval(). (this could be changed, if necessary, to automatically set all Exprs to false at the end of each eval.)

setLeaves

void setLeaves(java.lang.Object label)

tick

public void tick()
Advances the clock by one step. Subclasses should override this method to advance their subformulas.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()

valuate

final boolean valuate()
Recursively computes the value of the formula if necessary or returns the previously computed value.
